newsitem.title: THAILAND: Weak Thai stocks end at new 97-month lows.
newsitem.headline: Weak Thai stocks end at new 97-month lows.

text.p: Thai stocks ended at new 97-month lows on Friday on sustained absence of foreign investors and liquidation of bank stocks hit by weak earnings and low-quality assets, brokers said.
The composite SET index finished 4.16 points off at 515.60 on moderate 4.0 billion baht turnover. The SET-50 index dropped 0.21 points to 36.67.
"The current situation is very unfavourble to bank earnings. The non-performing loans problem also remained a major concern," said an analyst at United Securities.
The broker said the central bank measures to curb baht supply for currency speculators would raise the cost of offshore funding of Thai banks.
Some banks have in the past week delayed plans to float foreign bonds, putting them off until improvement of economic and money market conditions.
The Bank of Thailand has curbed offshore baht supply since the currency came under market attack in mid-May.
Foreign investors also remained on the sidelines after the central bank adopted measures to prevent foreign investors from raising baht through the stock market early this week, brokers said.
Bangkok Bank topped the active list, finishing four baht off at 139, Thai Farmers Bank eased one to 92, and Siam Commercial Bank fell one to 100.
TelecomAsia gained one to 25.25, and Siam Cement lost six to close at 430.
